resources.string: This device does not have a camera or a NFC reader./n Board scanning functions are disabled. Game mode unavailable
Run scanner and start to play
Place your device onto the NFC tag
Scan the QR code with your device

You can launch the game by scanning a NFC tag or QR code from an information board on the Sun trail with the scanner in this app.

In the game mode you can buy and sell items at each stop along the trail. You earn credits for trading these goods.
Before you finish the game at the last stop, try to earn as much as you can.

In the beginning you will be given a basic space ship. A trusworthy Ikarus M and a small amount of 42 space credits Which are used as money.

At each stop you must scan the code of the planet. Then you can enter the shop and trade items.

Certain items can be sold only on certain planets. Other items can be sold everywhere. You can read info about each item by tapping the red question mark either in the shop or in your inventory.

During the game you will have a chance to buy better, larger space ships. Those will allow you to transport larger amount of goods.

Based on how much credits you earn at the end of the game, you will be rewarded with a space fleet officer rank.

Have fun.

The belt between Mars and Jupiter contains a lot of objects which are smaller than asteroids. The first discovered one and also the largest of them all - 1000 km in size is Ceres. Next discovered objects were Pallas, Juno and Vesta. Non of them is observable by the bare eyes only. There is about 100 000 astronomical objects larger than 1 km. Their combined mass though is less than the mass of Mercury. Most of these objects have not had gone through the phase of remelting in the past. The temperature and pressure inside these small objects was not high enough. They therefore most probbaly consist of the type of rock from which larger planets formed.

The mythological origin of the name: Ceres was an Italian goddess of corn, grain, growth and agriculture.

Because of the existence of liquid water on Earth, it is the only planet known to support life. The Earth was formed about 4,56 milliard years ago, together with the Sun and other objects of the Solar system. It is almost the same planet as Mercury, Venus or Mars. It has an iron core and a thick rocky layer. The Earth is not exactly round – it is slightly flattened (the polar diameter is 12 714 km). The Earth orbits the Sun and rotates around it’s own axis. But it also makes other movements. The most significant is axial precession, which is the change in orientation of the Earth’s rotational axis, which happens every 26 500 years. Currently, the Earth’s axis points towards the star Polaris. The Solar system consists of eight orbiting planets but there are more than one thousand extrasolar planets, which orbit other stars.

The mythological origin of the name: The Greek name is Gaia, she was the mother of people and the gods.

Orbits of comets are usually elongated, alliptical and more inclined to the plane of ecliptic than the orbits of planets. When the comet approaches the Sun to the distance of Mars it heats up enough that the ice starts to sublime and a cloud of dust and gasses forms the cometary coma the nebulous envelope around the nucleus of a comet. Interactions with the Solar wind then creates the tail. You can only see the nucleus of the comet at this stop. While the nucleus is usually small - kilometers or tens of kilometers, the coma can be as large as thousands or even millions of kilometers. The tail can be more than 150 million km long (the distance between the Sun and the Earth). That would be hundrets of meters on our path.

The mythological origin of the name: comets are usually named by their discoverers. Although Edmund Halley (1656–1742) did not discover the comet, he was the first to predict the comet`s return.

Despite the fact that Jupiter weights less than 1/1000 of mass of the Sun, it is still the largest planet of the Solar system. Compared to the four inner planets, Jupiter and other outer planets have a relatively small rocky core, bulky hydrogen or icy layer, and a large and gradually thinning atmosphere. Consequently, we do not observe sharply defined surface boundaries for these outer planets. In 1610, Galileo Galilei discovered with his telescope four big moons of Jupiter: Io, Europa, Ganymede and Callisto. To show these moons in our model of Solar system, they would need to be around 3 mm in diameter and would orbit Jupiter in distances ranging from 42 to 189 cm.

The mythological origin of the name: Greek name is Zeus. He was the son of Titan Cronus and his wife Rhea. His grandfather was Uranus and grandmother was Gaia. Zeus was the Father of gods and men.

If you look at Mars you will immediately notice the distinctive red color. This is caused by iron oxides. White polar caps are made of ice CO2 and H2O. In the present liquid water can not exist on Mars because the atmosphere is too thin (atmospheric pressure on Mars is 100 times lower than on Earth). Mars has two small moons of irregular shapes: Phobos (27 km x 21 km x 19 km) abd Deimos. They are probably astronomical object caught by Marse`s gravity.

The mythological origin of the name: Mars was a Roman analogy to the Greek god of war Ares, the son of the highest gods Jupiter and Juno. Phobos and Deimos were a personification of Fear and Terror. They were Arese`s companions and appeared next to him in battles.

Planets, differently from the stars, do not shine by themselves but only reflect light from the Sun. Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun. Astronomers previously tried to discover a hypothetical planet Vulcan that would orbit even closer but were not successful. Even though Mercury is small (about the size of our Moon), it has a massive iron core.

The mythological origin of the name: Greek name is Hermes, who was Jupiter`s illegitimate son and Apollo’s (god of the Sun) brother. Mercury was a god with split personality: on one side, he was the god of wisdom but on the other, he was a deceitful thief.

The Moon orbits around the Earth as a natural satellite. Compared to the Earth, the Moon is four times smaller. Since it`s orbital period around Earth is the same as it`s sidereal rotation period, only one hemisphere of the Moon is always facing the Earth. This phenomenon is called rare rotation and it is caused by Earth`s tidal forces which slowed down original faster Moon`s rotation in the past. According to nowadays knowledge the Moon formed after the "proto-Earth" was hit by an astronomical object about the size of Mars. A large number of debris from the collision then either fell back onto Earth or formed a ring which later through collisions and gravity created the Moon.

The mythological origin of the name: the Moon is called "Luna" in poetry. This name comes from Latin. The Roman goddess who had this name was an analogy to the Greek Selene. Later also Artemis became the goddess of the Moon. Hekate was the goddess of the Moon in it`s invisible phase.

The Neptune is a planet which was first discovered by a mathematical calculation. Olny after that it was observed on the sky. J. C. Adams and independently U. J. J. Leverrier calculated Neptune`s orbit in the 1845 from Uranus orbit deviations. J. G. Galle found Neptune 1° beyond the predicted location. To see Neptune we definitely need a telescope. Until recently only two of Neptune`s moons were known: large Triton with a circular orbit and s small Nereid which has an elongated elliptical orbit (Nereid can get as far away as 110 diameters of Neptune).

The mythological origin of the name: the Neptune was an Italian god of water. Later was equated with Poseidon and became the ruler of the sea. With his trident he could upset the sea and shake the earth.

Neptune is the last stop of the Sun path of Křtiny. The beginning of the Sun path is located near Křitny elementary school.

Saturn is a giant gaseous planet with an average density lower than that of water. The most noticeable are the Saturn`s rings. They were first described only in 1655 by Christian Huygens. The rings consist of tiny particles (the size varies from 1cm to 100 m). These particles orbit Saturn in essentially a single plane. Saturn has numerous moons. The most mysterious is Titan with its methane atmosphere (the moon with 3000 km diameter has too low gravitation to permanently keep its gaseous atmosphere).

The mythological origin of the name: the Greek name is Kronos, who was the son of Uranus and Gaia. Saturn was the god of agriculture.

The Sun is a star. Compared to the other planets, it is a massive ball full of gas. The core temperature is about 15 million °C, the pressure is 2,48·10^16 Pa (the standard pressure on Earth is 101 325 Pa) and density is 162 000 kg/m3. Under these conditions, the nuclei of hydrogen atoms fuse to form helium atoms and generate photons and neutrinos. Photon luminosity of the Sun is 3,85 · 10^26 W. Energy of about 342W per 1 m2 lands on Earth and this energy enables the existence of life on our planet. The Sun is between 4.6 to 4.7 billion years old and it will continue to shine for another 5 billion years. At the end of its life, the Sun will go through the state of a red giant. At the speed of about 1 000km/s, the atmosphere of this red giant will separate to expose the Sun`s core. This event will be observable as a cooling white dwarf and its expanding cover will create planetary nebula.

The mythological origin of the name: people were always aware of the Sun’s existence. Many of their gods were linked to the Sun. In the ancient Egypt, god of the Sun was called Ra. For Greeks, the god of the Sun was Apollo.

Uranus was discovered only with the use of telescopes due to its small size, which is at the limits of visibility by naked eye. Rings of the Uranus are extremely dark (they reflect only about 4% of the sunshine) and were located indirectly in 1977, when the planet overlaid a star. The unique feature of Uranus is the greatly tilted axis of rotation - it lies close to its plane of revolution about the Sun and, as a consequence, we observe alternating north or south poles of the planet.

The mythological origin of the name: Uranus; together with Gaia, was the oldest god on Earth. He arose out of night. The names of Uranus`s moons are interesting, because they do not come from the Greek mythology but from the theater plays of William Shakespeare (e.g. Titania, Oberon, Miranda, Ariel, Umbriel).

The Venus is always shrouded into dense clouds. Therefore direct sunlight can not be seen from the surface. High surface temperature (Even higher than on Mercury) is caused by the greenhouse effect - visible sunlight passes through the atmosphere, heats up the surface which then radiates in infrared radiation. This radiation is effectively absorbed by the atmosphere heating it up. Similar process is happening in Earth`s atmosphere but it is less effective. The planet Venus revolves around it`s axis very slowly and to the opposite direction than the direction Venus orbits around the Sun.

The mythological origin of the name: the Venus was a Roman analogy to the Greek goddess of love, beauty and fertility - Aphrodite. She was born from the sea foam which came to existence from the penis of castrated Uranus.

Next stop
